content:
I'd love to know what makes you think you have to donate because you definitely don't have to, you're merely asked to donate if you want, that's why it's a donation, not a purchase…

My first try was a new password because there was no indication of which was required. […] Do I really have to have a password on account setup?

If you're trying to set up a mail account in Thunderbird, of course you'll have to provide the password for that account. That's what the password is for, so nobody can access your mail without knowing the password. If you didn't have to use your password for that, then anyone would be able to get access to your mail by merely knowing your email address and setting up your mail account on his/her computer… The indication of which password is required is the very fact that you're trying to get access to your mail account. What other indication would you need?

You appear to not be correctly configuring the account with the right settings, though. Maybe you're trying to configure automatically an account that you have to Configure manually because Thunderbird doesn't know what the settings for that account should be, and that's why the set up process may fail even if you're using the right password, but you'll have to give more details about which is your email provider and the settings you're trying to use for anyone here to be able to assist. A screenshot (without showing any passwords) would help…

content: In TB, a .msf file is an index of mail that is stored in the mbox file with the same name, e.g. folder.msf and folder (no extension). If you can recover the mbox file, it can be imported to TB - the .msf file is unnecessary as the mbox contains all the message content. The .msf is automatically recreated after mbox import.

content:
if the image is 10 MB, will there then be 10MB less left of the C drive’s total storage space?

It does actually take more, but you don't have to guess, you may make Thunderbird show how much space each message takes by using Table View (you must be using Cards View if you're asking this question), and add the Size column if not already shown:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/getting-started-thunderbird-main-window-supernova

is there any way to move the whole Thunderbird (emails with images) over to the D drive

I'd move the whole profile folder and keep it all together rather than the local directory of each of the accounts, for which I provide instructions below, BUT… before you do any of that… Are you sure you want to keep all those images in your mail? Wouldn't it be preferable to save them, organise them separately however you wish, and remove them from the messages they came with?

Anyway, to move the profile folder to a new location on drive D…

Check the following article to see what's a profile and how to locate the profile folder, but don't follow the instructions given there to move the profile unless you feel comfortable manually editing the profiles.ini file as described there:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data

Do this instead:

  1. In Thunderbird, choose File > Offline > Work Offline from the menu bar, so Thunderbird doesn't connect to the server while you're doing this.
  2. Locate the profile folder you want to move to another drive.
  3. Quit Thunderbird.
  4. Copy (don't remove from the original location yet) the profile folder to the desired new location.
  5. Launch Thunderbird, choose Help > Troubleshooting Information from the menu bar and click on the about:profiles link there to open the About Profiles built-in Profile Manager.
  6. Create a New Profile, read the introductory text if this is new to you, then click Continue. You may name the profile however you want, but I'd choose a name such as "D-Drive" that makes it clear this is a profile stored outside of the default location.
  7. Click Choose Folder to choose the profile folder in the new location, then click Done.
  8. Click Launch Profile under the new profile in the profile manager to start using the new profile. Don't go online yet, make sure first that everything is working as expected. In particular, you may check the Server Settings > Location Directory of your mail accounts to see that your mail is now being stored where you expect.
  9. Go back to the profile manager. The new profile may have already been set as the default. If not, use the Set as default button under it to make it so.
  10. Remove the old profile. You'll be given the option to Delete Files, which is the very reason we're doing this.
  11. Tell thunderbird to go back online by unchecking File > Offline > Work Offline.

You may see similar instructions to accomplish the same using an external Profile Manager tool. That additional complication is unnecessary. Recent versions of Thunderbird have the built-in version of the Profile Manager I've been referring to that may be used instead. Both versions of the Profile Manager are documented in the following article:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/profile-manager-create-and-remove-thunderbird-profiles

content: Attachments can be added from received or sent messages, to new messages, by drag and drop.
creator: sfhowes

content:
sfhowes said
Attachments can be added from received or sent messages, to new messages, by drag and drop.

Drag and drop does not always work correctly. It is timing-dependent. If the auto-save function saves a draft automatically while you are writing the message, Thunderbird will throw an error saying it was unable to save the message. This error will persist until the dropped attachment is removed from the new message.

https://assets-prod.sumo.prod.webservices.mozgcp.net/media/uploads/images/2025-04-04-14-00-54-b935f3.png

Drag and drop will appear to add the attachment to the new message, but Thunderbird will have a problem saving it as a draft. It tries to save as a draft during the Send process and fails.

https://assets-prod.sumo.prod.webservices.mozgcp.net/media/uploads/images/2025-04-04-14-01-08-56c0af.png

The only workaround is to save the attachment from the original email to a file, then attach the file as a new attachment in the new message.
creator: efeaglehouse

content:
sfhowes said
Attachments can be added from received or sent messages, to new messages, by drag and drop.

Drag and drop does not always work correctly. It is timing-dependent. If Thunderbird attempts to auto-save a draft using a dropped attachment, it will report a failure to save the draft. This error will persist until the attachment is removed.

https://assets-prod.sumo.prod.webservices.mozgcp.net/media/uploads/images/2025-04-04-14-03-52-b935f3.png

When attempting to send the message, Thunderbird apparently attempts to save a draft copy before the send and fails.

https://assets-prod.sumo.prod.webservices.mozgcp.net/media/uploads/images/2025-04-04-14-05-49-56c0af.png

The only workaround is to save the attachment from the original message as a file, then attach that file to the new message.
creator: efeaglehouse

content:
Re Thunderbird no longer sends emails .. I don't know if my problem was/is? related to that of sparrow17m, but I too had problems. Prior to that described below, I had been using Thunderbird for at least three years without problems . I very much appreciate the capability provided by Thunderbird.

Somewhat suddenly on February 13th, I could not use Thunderbird to collect (receive) or send messages to/from my @Gmail.com account. The problem was also preventing Thunderbird from sending/receiving Email messages via my personal URL (@LArents.biz) on InMotionHosting. The attached image was recorded using the version of Thunderbird is hosted on a Win7 machine with Norton 360. I encountered essentially the same problems on another similarly configured but rarely used Win7 machine as well as a Win10 machine, so I deduced the problem was not machine specific.

Thunderbird was also unable to save sent messages in my sent folder. I think the error message was that it could not find the folder.

The outgoing eMail problem seemed to be associated with my lacking some security certificate as indicated in attached image.. After several hours of intense work trying various settings to get Thunderbird to ignore the security warnings or use an alternative port, I was frustrated. Then when I was about to make additional attempts, for unknown reasons, Thunderbird SUDDENLY started working on the evening of February 14th without my having implemented additional changes.

I suspect some interaction with Norton360 but I just hope things continue to work.

I think the problem has gone away, but it will take additional checking to confirm.

Comments will be welcomed.
creator: WindsurferLA

content: The SMTP policy reasons are probably being caused by you using a VPN to mask your real IP address. If that's the case, check whether your VPN has an option called split tunneling which would allow you to let Thunderbird bypass the VPN. Otherwise you'll have to disable the VPN to be able to send with that SMTP server.

content:
You cannot retrieve the password with Thunderbird, you can only tell it what the password is supposed to be. You can only reset or change the password at the website of your email provider (and somehow authenticate or prove your identity there). If you could simply retrieve the password whenever you forget it, anyone would be able to do the same to get access to your mail account and the password would be useless…

That said, according to this web page, you may need to generate an app password and use that instead of the account password in Thunderbird. The article isn't clear about this and gives the impression that the app password is only required for smartphone apps, but I wouldn't be surprised if it's required for mail clients in general:

https://www.virginmedia.com/help/broadband/manage-email-settings

And you may want to try using these other settings instead:

https://www.postbox-inc.com/setup/email-settings/access-ntlworld-com-via-imap-smtp

creator: davidsk

content:
Doesn't Thunderbird give you the option to enter a new password when it fails to connect to the server? If you cannot enter the new password there, you may remove or update the password kept by Thunderbird as follows:

  1. Go to Settings > Privacy & Security > Saved Passwords.
  2. Click Show Passwords if you'll want to change the password. You won't be able to edit the password unless you do this first.
  3. Look for the password that has changed.
  4. Either select the password and click Remove to make Thunderbird ask for it the next time (make sure you've selected the right password before removing it), or right-click on it, choose Edit Password and type the new password there.
  5. Restart Thunderbird if the problem persists. You may need to do that for the changes to take effect, not sure.

content:
If you are using sort by Threaded and the Threads are in a collapsed state: If you select the top level collapsed state thread email and click on Delete or use Right click and click on the Delete bin icon, you will get a pop up messages which says "This will delete messages in collapsed threads. Are you sure you want to continue?" If you click on 'Delete' button - it will delete all threads in that collapsed thread.

If you delete any single email not in a thread then email follows the instruction set up in account settings for the account. eg: Move it to the TRash You do not get a warning when only deleting a single email and it is going to a designated folder.


If you use the 'Shift' + 'Del' key This will pop up a message that says: " This will delete messages immediately, without saving a copy to Deleted. Are you sure you want to continue? " If you click on 'Delete' button - it will delete the email and by pass the Trash. There is no Undo option. This is very use if you use a Gmail imap account and have same email stored in various folders but you only want to remove a label not delete actual email from the 'All Mail' store, so it means any other copies with labels for other folders will still be visible.

If you want to Empty the Deleted/Trash folder Right click on Trash folder and select 'Empty Deleted' You will see a prompt: "Delete all messages and subfolders in the Deleted folder?" Click on 'YES' and it removes all emails and subfolders that exist in the 'Trash'.

If you do not use that 'Empty Deleted' option but instead select an email that is already in the TRash then you should get a prompt: "This will permantely delete messages from Deleted. Are you sure you want to continue?" Clicking on 'Delete' - just deletes that particular email from the Trash.


IF you select several separate emails that are not threaded they will display as X conversation in the Message Pane When you click on 'Delete' button - it means they all get move to TRash or as per Account Settings. There is no warning but the Undo Delete is an option.

There are several different warnings and it also depends upon what you have selected. I suggest you attempt to delete an email from Inbox in order to invoke that pop up message - then get a screenshot which shows: you have selected the 'Inbox' folder You have selected one single email in list The warning pop up message

Obviously do not click on the Delete.

Upload that image file to this forum question.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
How are you adding the contacts to the 'Mailing List' ? How many contacts are already in that 'Mailing List' ?

The contact must already be in whatever 'address book' which has the 'Mailing List' as a sub group. The contact must have a valid email address.

You select the contact to highlight then left click and hold down to grab contact and then drag contact to the left pane and hover over the Mailing List name - release to drop into the list.

You cannot use drag and drop etc if the contact is not in the address book which has the mailing list as a sub group.

If you reacted to the appeal in Thunderbird which suggested you change to 139, then you saw https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-release/ which also has the instructions for going back to 128.

Before you do that, you might want to try some easy steps, and if they help then some recommendations can be made to help you:

1. If you do not like the cards view display then change to table view.

2. If you are seeing a performance problem or some other issue then

  • Start Windows in safe mode with networking enabled - https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/12376/windows-10-start-your-pc-in-safe-mode
  • Still In Windows safe mode, start Thunderbird in Troubleshoot Mode - https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/troubleshoot-mode-thunderbird

Does problem change?

content: It should. How would Thunderbird users have been able to transition from one architecture to the other otherwise? Potential problems, if any, would be more likely to arise as a result of the big difference in Thunderbird version number from the PPC version to the Intel one, not from moving a profile folder created on a PPC Mac to an Intel one.
creator: DavidGG

content: I'll give it a try. A lot of PPC applications were incompatible with intel....
creator: themuttfactor1

content:
A lot of PPC applications were incompatible with intel

That would be the application itself and could be the case for Thunderbird as well, but not for the data stored in your profile folder, i.e. using your data with the right version of Thunderbird for the computer architecture you're using shouldn't be a problem.
creator: DavidGG

content:
Here's an article that would seem to indicate a big difference in version numbers could be a problem: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/upgrading-older-version-thunderbird

And here's another that explains a new version of Thunderbird may create a new profile instead of using the one you have: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/recover-user-data-missing-after-thunderbird-update

So you may indeed find some problems moving from PPC to Intel, but because of the different Thunderbird versions used in each case, not because of moving your data from PPC to Intel.
creator: DavidGG
